title: Comparative Adjectives
rule: Add -er + than to compare two things.
example: Tom is taller than Bob.

title: Superlative Adjectives
rule: Add -est to show the highest degree among three or more.
example: Tom is the tallest student in his class.

title: Indefinite Adjectives
rule: Describe nouns in a non-specific way.
example: Some people like coffee.

title: Adjectives
rule: Describe or modify nouns. Usually come before the noun.
example: She has a big house.

title: Adverbs
rule: Describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs.
example: He runs quickly.

title: Adverbs of Frequency
rule: Tell how often something happens. Place before main verb, after BE.
example: She is always late.

title: Verb 'Use'
rule: Can be followed by a noun/pronoun and either a gerund or infinitive.
example: I use a laptop for work.

title: Indefinite Pronouns
rule: Refer to people or things in a general way.
example: Someone is at the door.

title: Comparatives
rule: Use comparative adjectives to compare two things.
example: This book is more interesting than that one.

title: Long Comparatives
rule: Use more/less + adjective with 2+ syllables. Add 'than'.
example: She is more beautiful than her sister.

title: Superlatives
rule: Use superlative adjectives to show highest or lowest degree.
example: He is the best player on the team.

title: Whom
rule: Ask about the object of a verb or preposition.
example: To whom did you speak?

title: Possessive Pronouns
rule: Show ownership and replace a noun + adjective.
example: This book is mine.

title: Mental Verbs + Infinitive
rule: Use mental verbs + to + base verb as direct object.
example: I decided to leave.

title: Be Going To (Future)
rule: Use 'be going to' for future plans.
example: I am going to travel tomorrow.

title: Be Going To (Questions)
rule: Begin sentence with BE to ask about future plans.
example: Are you going to study tonight?

title: Wh- Questions (Future)
rule: Use WH + BE going to + subject.
example: What are you going to do?

title: Reported Commands
rule: Use 'tell' + person + that-clause.
example: She told me that I should wait.

title: May / Might
rule: Talk about possibility (uncertain).
example: It may rain tomorrow.

title: Predicate Adjectives + That-Clause
rule: Some adjectives are followed by a that-clause.
example: I am sure that he is right.

title: How (Method)
rule: Ask in what way or method.
example: How do you make bread?

title: Because
rule: Connect two clauses. Explains reason.
example: I stayed home because it was raining.

title: Adverbs of Manner
rule: Describe how an action is done.
example: He speaks slowly.

title: Comparative Adjectives (Similar/Different)
rule: Show if things are same, similar, or different.
example: My car is as fast as yours.

title: Noun Clauses
rule: Use that-clause after mental verbs as object.
example: I think that he is right.

title: Present Progressive (Future)
rule: Use to talk about planned future events.
example: I am meeting him tomorrow.

title: Linking Verbs
rule: Connect subject to description (not action).
example: She is a teacher.

title: Past Progressive
rule: Action in progress at a specific past time.
example: I was studying at 8 PM.

title: Reported Requests
rule: Use ask/tell + person + to + base verb.
example: She told me to sit down.

title: Should (Advice)
rule: Say what is the right/best thing to do.
example: You should eat healthy food.

title: Could (Suggestions)
rule: Offer polite ideas/options.
example: You could try restarting your computer.

title: Apologize For
rule: Use 'apologize for' + -ing verb.
example: I apologize for being late.

title: Dummy 'It'
rule: Use 'it' for time, weather, distance.
example: It is raining.

title: Adverbs of Time
rule: Connect two actions/events by showing when.
example: I will call you after dinner.

title: How Far
rule: Ask about distance between two places.
example: How far is it from here to Riyadh?

title: Prepositions of Place
rule: Show location with a noun.
example: The book is on the table.

title: Simple Present (Future Events)
rule: Talk about scheduled future events.
example: The train leaves at 6 PM.

title: Gerunds
rule: -ing form used as a noun.
example: Swimming is fun.

title: Be Supposed To
rule: Talk about expectations.
example: I am supposed to finish this today.

title: How + Infinitive
rule: Use after verbs like know, learn, show.
example: She taught me how to swim.

title: Modal Requests
rule: Use could/would for polite requests.
example: Could you help me?

title: Adjectives + Infinitive
rule: Some adjectives are followed by to + base verb.
example: I am happy to see you.

title: Reported Commands (to + verb)
rule: Tell someone what another person said to do.
example: He told me to wait outside.

title: Ability Modal (Be able to)
rule: Show ability across different tenses.
example: She is able to drive.

title: Adjective Clauses
rule: Describe a noun, usually follow it.
example: The man who is wearing a hat is my uncle.

title: Too / Enough
rule: Show something is more than needed or not suitable.
example: It is too hot to play outside.

title: Adjective Suffix -y
rule: Turns nouns into adjectives, meaning 'full of'.
example: The sky is cloudy.

title: How Long
rule: Ask about length of time.
example: How long have you lived here?

title: Prepositions of Time
rule: Show when something happens.
example: We met at 5 oâ€™clock.

title: Indefinite Pronouns (People)
rule: Refer generally to people when identity unknown.
example: Anybody can join.

title: Present Perfect (Continuing)
rule: Actions that started in past and continue now.
example: I have lived here for 10 years.

title: Present Perfect (Experiences)
rule: Ask about experiences up to now.
example: Have you ever been to Japan?

title: Infinitive of Purpose
rule: Show reason or purpose with to + verb.
example: I study to pass the test.

title: Become / Get
rule: Show a change of state.
example: She became tired.

title: Could (Past Ability)
rule: Say someone was able to do something in past.
example: I could swim when I was a child.

title: Ability vs. Possibility
rule: Could/can show ability; may/might show possibility.
example: She can play piano. It might rain.

title: Present Perfect Continuous
rule: Talk about actions that started in past and still continue.
example: I have been studying all day.

title: Reported Speech
rule: Say what someone else said.
example: She said she was tired.

title: -ed vs -ing Adjectives
rule: -ed describes feelings, -ing describes causes.
example: I am bored. The movie is boring.

title: Present Perfect (Result)
rule: Use to describe a situation that began in past and continues.
example: He has worked here since 2010.

title: Comparative Adverbs
rule: Use -er or more to compare actions.
example: She runs faster than her brother.

title: Adverbs of Time
rule: Tell when something happens.
example: I saw him yesterday.

title: Conditional (Real)
rule: Use 'if' to talk about real/likely conditions.
example: If it rains, we will stay inside.

title: Conjunctions (Or/So)
rule: Or = choice, So = result.
example: You can have tea or coffee. It was late, so I left.

title: Reported Speech (Say/Said)
rule: Change verb tense from present â†’ past.
example: He says he is tired â†’ He said he was tired.

title: Could (Possibility)
rule: Talk about something possible but not certain.
example: He could be the new manager.

title: Used To
rule: Talk about past routines or conditions, not true now.
example: I used to play football every day.

title: Would (Past Habit)
rule: Talk about things done regularly in the past.
example: When I was young, I would visit my grandmother often.

title: Present Perfect (Past Actions)
rule: Talk about actions that happened at some time before now.
example: I have eaten sushi.

title: Present Perfect WH-Questions
rule: Ask about past experiences with WH-word.
example: What have you done today?
